Well I am keeping it simple. In fact the "activation level" in most 
ANNs m=
eans "spike frequency".. Leaky integrators are good because 
even if the CP=
PN produces an organism without sensor tissues, it's 
neural network can st=
ill have internal neural network activity 
essentialy exhibiting a nice rea=
listic oscillating pattern. This 
might be useful, for example for a swimmi=
ng creature. 
Temperature or other stuff is not considered here. You should=
 
understand that I start this from scratch and I want to keep it as 
simpl=
e a possible for now. Besides, I am developing this in my spare 
time only,=
 I don't have much free time since I got this my now job 
involving neural =
networks. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken Lloyd" <kalloyd@...> w=
rote:
>
> Leaky integrators?  Going back to a physical analogy, the network=
 
graph can
> also relate to bond graphs or mechatronic graphs.  The input =
and 
output
> nodes can exhibit something akin to impedance in an electroni=
c 
circuit -
> depending upon the frequency in which they are activated.  T=
his 
means (with
> a little help from complex numbers) that the connections=
 can emit 
heat,
> which affects the local thermodynamics of the various gr=
aph nodes.
>  
> Is this consistent with your concept of a leaky integrator=
?
>  
> Obviously, this adds a bit of computational complexity to the mix -=
 
but the
> force displacement vectors can be easily computed on graphics 
=
processor
> unit(s) - which is probably beyond the scope of this thread.
> =
 
> Ken Lloyd

node/s for two reasons. One is that I can't 
find

for them. The second is that I am going to 
use

inputs are not well suited for them. I let 
> the CPPN output the time cons=
tants and bias instead. 
> I constrain the experiment to 2D for simplicity.=
 If it proves to be 
> interesting, I will extend to 3D easily. This will b=
ump up the 
> dimentionality of the CPPN input/output space, though.

Peter

ive CPPNs for Alife domains
> >

> > 
> > Hi again :) 
> > 
> > I am d=
eveloping an Alife pet project evolving 2D mass-spring 
based 
> > creature=
s. The fitness function can't exactly be defined, since 
> they 
> > can be=
 evolved towards some tasks like "go there" or something. I 
> > want to br=
iefly describe the details behind it. 
> > 
> > The same network is used fo=
r both the body and the nervous system 
> of 
> > the creature. First the b=
ody is built by a spatial CPPN and 
> converted 
> > to a mass-spring model=
. There are several tissues (the CPPN 
outputs 
> > tissue type instead of =
level of expression). One type of tissue 
is 
> a 
> > sensor tissue, which=
 excites upon collision. Another type of 
tissue 
> > is a muscle tissue, w=
hich contracts the springs when excited. 
Like 
> a 
> > regular bilogical =
muscle. 
> > 
> > The key point is, that after the spatial CPPN builds the =
body, 
the 
> > same CPPN is then used for HyperNEAT (additional outputs, 
=
though), 
> to 
> > evolve the connectivity of the neural network controlli=
ng the 
body. 
> > Inputs are located on sensor tissue only. Outputs are lo=
cated on 
> > muscle tissue. Hidden nodes are located on the remaining tiss=
ue. 
> This 
> > is essentially evolving both the substrate and the connect=
ivity 
of 
> > the network, but in a meaningful way, because of the geometr=
y and 
> the 
> > simulated 2D physics space. 
> > 
> > The simulation is l=
ike this - when the sensor tissue is excited 
by 
> > some collision, this =
also plugs 1.0 into the associated 
HyperNEAT's 
> > network's inputs. When=
 the outputs activation level exceeds some 
> > treshold, the associated sp=
rings on the muscle tissue are 
> contracted. 
> > 
> > I believe that usin=
g the same network for both pusposes (spatial 
> and 
> > connective) is be=
tter than using different networks. Do you think 
> > this in general is a =
good idea? 
> > 
> > Peter
> >
>
